columns.text: Here we need to do a ratio analysis of S&S Air by comparing the performance of the company to the industry. We are required to take into consideration every ratio calculated.

Here we have the industry information and S&S Air:

Ratio|	Lower Quartile |	Median |	Upper Quartile 	|S&S Air |
|--|--|--|--|--|
Current ratio|	0.50	|1.43	|1.89	|0.74
Quick ratio|	0.21	|0.35	|0.62	|0.39
Cash ratio|	0.08	|0.21	|0.39	|0.15
Total asset turnover 	|0.68	|0.85|	1.38	|2.01
Inventory turnover |	4.89|	6.15	|10.89	|27.96
Receivables turnover 	|6.27	|9.82	|14.11	|54.91
Total debt ratio 	|0.41	|0.52|	0.61|	0.43
Debt-equity ratio |	0.68	|1.08	|1.56|	0.74
Equity multiplier 	|1.68	|2.08	|2.56	|1.74
Times interest earned |	5.18	|8.06	|9.83	|5.26
Cash coverage ratio |	5.84	|9.41|10.27	|8.12
Profit margin |	4.05%	|5.10%	|7.15%|	5.01%
Return on assets 	|6.05%|	9.53%	|13.21%|	10.08%
Return on equity |	9.93%	|15.14%	|19.15%|	17.59%

First, we are going to analyze the short-term solvency ratios:

- Current ratio
- Quick ratio
- Cash ratio

The **current and cash ratio** of S&S is lower than the industry median which means they are less solvent than their peers on average, however, they are not in the lower quartile either. Moreover, the **quick ratio** es slightly above average which means that a big part of their short term assets is the inventory which is considered the "least liquid" current assets.

Next, we will analyze the turnover ratios: 

- Total asset turnover 
- Inventory turnover 
- Receivables turnover 

When we see the **total asset turnover and the inventory turnover ratio**, they are significantly greater than the upper quartile. This is a good sign since it tells us that they are very effective using their assets to create sales and that they have a high rotation of inventory respectively. 

On the other hand, the **receivables turnover ratio** is quite high, much more than the upper quartile, which is a bad sign as it suggest that S&S is not effective at all collecting their payments, which could suggest that most if not all of their sales are payed with credit which is riskier for the business,

The following analysis is about the long-term solvency ratios:

- Total debt ratio 
- Debt-equity ratio 
- Equity multiplier
- Times interest earned 
- Cash coverage ratio 

First the **total debt ratio** is slightly lower than the industry standard and this is a good sign as this suggest that they are not over leveraged in comparison to their peers. However, we can see that the industry is a highly leveraged one which of course makes it more susceptible to volatility. 

When it comes to the **debt-equity ratio and equity multiplier**, both are considerably less than the median but not part of the lower quartile. This is a good sign as it suggest as well S&S is not over leveraged compared to their peers and this makes it easier to borrow funds as it suggest good financial health.

When it comes to the **times interest earned**, it is considerably lower that the median almost being part of the lower quartile. This suggest that even they might not be on the same level of leverage as their peers because they are not able to acquire more as will highly affect their ability to meet their financial obligations if operations do not grow.

On the other hand, the **cash coverage ratio** is slightly under the industry median which further suggest what was mentioned about the times interest earned, however, we see that cash has a big impact on solvency when taken into account in the case of S&S.

Finally we move on to analyze the profitability ratios for S&S Air:

- Profit margin 
- Return on assets 
- Return on equity 

For all this ratios we can observe that S&S Air in on-par with the industry median. This suggest that they are operating to the same degree in terms of profitability as the industry. Moreover, this suggest that maybe the company has a good governance as they able to perform as good as the industry on average in a highly competitive market (aerospace).
